positive.review:
Pretty damn good, though there are some pretty tedious errors in the story and environment.
With this games much smaller map, there are less species, which makes sense- until you realize majority of biomes are lucky to even have 4 total animals. and some where theres a mere two only. Which is quite a let down, however a handful of the species introduced in this game are some of my absolute favourites across either game.

As for the story, it starts out kind of fine, and for the most part goes over well, but the ending is, while heartwarming, illogical. I will not go into spoilers, but that is a strong let down in my eyes. However I will note that apart from those holes, the characters (especially alan) are very fun, which is better than out paper figure in the original.

While it is not superior to the original subnautica, it is still pretty good, despite it's issues. I enjoyed it.
No, it's not as good as its predecessor. That does not keep it from being an all around solid game with loads to explore, build and have fun with.

I love Subnautica, the original is probably one of my all time favorite videogames, so please read this review with the understanding that I may be somewhat biased. Short review, I liked this and think its worth a playthrough. A slightly more nuanced take is that while enjoyable, there's a *lot* of minor issues that stacked up to making this game feel like it struggled and in many places failed to live up to its full potential. I'll name those that aren't spoilers first, and then dive into those after.

First off, the game has some issues with polish. There's a lot of design decisions that feel ill thought out or only partially implemented, and there are enough bugs and problems where its not an incidental problem. The first is that its incredibly easy to get stuck without a way to recover in areas that are accessible but clearly weren't intended to be. For instance, I used the snowfox to explore some of the wider glaciers and wound up stuck on the roof of outpost zero. There's a small pocket there where you can't go back up but can't go down off the roof because there's invisible walls on every side. There's also a lot of item spawning issues. I had over a dozen instances where ore or scan-ables were visible or were picked up by my scanning room, but were inside of a wall, or embedded in the ground, or nestled in rocks. In all those situations, they were irretrievable. This was especially true for the above-water ore veins, where I found the ones in the edges weren't able to be grabbed basically every time. I also had issues with the sea creature movement and behavior, which I'll detail more in the spoiler section.  Finally, I found it frustrating that some of the hab features would be non-scannable in some locations but would be in others, without any clear reason why. Again, I'll detail more below.

Spoilers

[spoiler] Ok, going into more detail on the things I talked about. First, there feels like a significant amount of the planned content was cut. There are sections of hab in some of the bases, and areas behind the closed doors in the mining bases that are filled with loot but are totally inaccessible. Why model interiors and place the loot if you're just going to leave them closed off? Is it really that much more work to open them up to the player? The progression in this game also felt a lot less meaningful than in the original game. For the most part the only reason you should acquire anything more difficult than a basic survival setup is to create single-use story items, and for some there's not even that. (The spy-pengling reeks of cut content for instance). Why leave nickel in the game if you only need five ore total ever to get depth upgrades for the truck and the prawn? There's also some frustrating ore clusters near the end of the crystal zone where you need the mk2 depth upgrade for the prawn to reach and mine them, but once you have that upgrade you don't need the kyanite anymore. Why put an item in a place where you only reach it once its no longer useful? Speaking of the crystal biome, the leviathans down there are some of the worst parts of either of the games. Despite being one of the largest leviathans in the game, they're placed in an area so small they really struggle to navigate it. They constantly get stuck on corners or in tight bends. They also have a much larger grab hitbox than you'd think, regularly grabbing my  prawn from behind their head or from several meters away. Given that, I found that it was easier to just wait for them to inevitably get stuck and punch them to death with the prawn suit.  It turned what should have been the final late-game danger in the game into a frustrating chore. On that note, basically none of the dangerous creatures are as dangerous or aggressive as in the original game. Most will ignore you unless you get within a handful of meters of them, and basically all of them will run if they bump your vehicle or take a single knife strike. Below Zero will not challenge you like the original game did, flat out. Finally, there's a few places where base pieces feel like they should have been scannable, but weren't for some reason. For instance, in the omega base, the wall planters and ivy wall pieces aren't scannable, so you have to wait until you finish working with Marguerite to get those pieces for some reason. [/spoiler]

With the stuff that I didn't like out of the way, there's a lot that I did enjoy greatly. First off, the additions to the basebuilding were excellent. I loved building my hab in the first game, and getting more cosmetic and flavor recipes in the sequel was a lot of fun. Building a base that was beautiful and functional was and remained my biggest time sink in both games. I also really liked the new creatures designs and presence. They continued to nail the beautiful and dangerous vibe. The inclusion of oxygen plants and the circle fish were also good inclusions, that gameified and expanded your ability to dive for extended periods. Finally, I really liked Robin as the MC. She brought a lot more to the game than Ryley did as a silent protagonist. Along with the inclusion of [spoiler] Al-an and bringing back Marguerite (the GOAT) [/spoiler] The game felt a lot less lonely than the original, in a really pleasant way. 

This is already getting too long, but ultimately its worth a play, especially if you're a fan of the original, but its less polished and you shouldn't expect an experience of the same quality. 6.5/10

Although there is more voice acting and missing the fact that you are alone on an alien world, where you feel like you are alone, and that there are no signs that people have been there recently, I would most definitely recommend this game to other players

In Subnautica 1 the story leaned very heavily on the "show, don't tell" approach while letting you explore and survive. In Below Zero however, the protagonist is given a personality, voice lines, and even another living human being to interact with. While this did somewhat help give the player more direction with what to do and where to go, it made the game feel less like you're exploring an alien planet and more like a safari tour. I'd still recommend this game but it definitely isn't as memorable as Subnautica 1.

Subnautica: Below Zero was more of what I wanted after playing the original. Unlike some of the other reviews, I enjoyed the voice acting and the PDAs, which made the story feel more engaging. The base building was great even for someone who usually skips decorating in survival crafting, I found myself making living areas just for fun. The art direction surpassed the original game, with vibrant colors that made the plant feel more alien. My only issue was with the Seatruck, I liked the concept and what it did for the most part, but it was a rigid stick when it should have been more like a jointed train car.

Very good game. exploration is fun, but it can be challenging. 
The terror I felt when Going into certain ereas is like something I could never expect. If you are someone looking for a thrill to play. This is a great choice.

10/10 recommend.

Subnautica Below Zero is a solid follow up to the first game, the frozen biomes give it a fresh atmosphere, and while the world is smaller and the story more compact, it still captures that feeling of slowly uncovering an alien world piece by piece. It’s a cool, enjoyable return to Planet 4546B.

Subnautica: Below Zero — Dive Into an Icy Alien Adventure

Subnautica: Below Zero takes players back to the depths of the alien ocean, exploring an uncharted region of the same planet from the first game. Exploration, survival, and discovery are at the core of the experience, inviting players to dive into a vibrant underwater world filled with strange creatures, hidden biomes, and captivating secrets.

The game excels in exploration and survival mechanics. Building bases, crafting tools, and managing oxygen while navigating freezing waters creates constant tension and excitement. Every dive brings new creatures, resources, and mysteries, making the world feel alive and rewarding curiosity.

Progression is satisfying and immersive. Unlocking new vehicles, gadgets, and habitat modules feels meaningful, giving a sense of accomplishment as you uncover the story behind the alien planet. The balance of challenge and exploration ensures each playthrough is engaging, with optional objectives encouraging creativity and experimentation.

Visually, Below Zero is stunning. From icy caverns to glowing alien flora, the game’s environments are vibrant and detailed, with fluid underwater physics and beautiful atmospheric effects. The sound design and music enhance the tension and wonder, making every dive memorable.

[h3]Final Verdict:[/h3]
Subnautica: Below Zero is an immersive, visually striking survival adventure. Combining engaging exploration, clever survival mechanics, and a captivating story, it’s a must-play for fans of open-world underwater adventures.

“A chilling, beautiful, and endlessly fascinating underwater journey that rewards curiosity and careful planning.”

Overall Rating: ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐☆☆ 8/10

Rapaz… eu achei que já tinha passado sufoco no Subnautica normal. Aí fui jogar o Below Zero e descobri que dá pra congelar, levar susto, passar fome e ainda ser humilhado por um pinguim alienígena. Tudo isso em 5 minutos de gameplay.

Você chega no planeta e já pensa:
“Beleza, agora eu morro de hipotermia antes do Leviatã me comer.”

Aí começa a farra:
– Vou pegar recurso → começa nevasca nível “SP em julho”.
– Vou usar meu veículo novinho → Leviatã pega e fala “hmm lanche”.

E os pinguins, meu amigo…
Eles têm cara de fofinho, mas se chegar perto eles gritam igual criança no supermercado que viu um brinquedo de 200 conto. E você corre, porque sabe que se fosse no Brasil já estavam roubando seu bolsa família.

O jogo inteiro é um grande “ai meu Deus, socorro” misturado com “caraca que lugar lindo” e no final você fica lá feliz, traumatizado e com 3 veículos quebrados porque decidiu explorar “só mais um pouquinho”.

Resumo BR:
Jogo top.
Te assusta, te humilha, te congela, mas te diverte.
10/10 — Melhor terapia que já fiz e ainda sai mais barato que gás de cozinha.

I support the main developers(from the top brass down to the smallest roles) and hope they receive the benefits/incentives they were promised, and that the parties guilty of greedy practices tainting a game franchise so loved by the gaming community get what is coming to them. Pay out the money Krafton, corporate suits destroy a great product once again.

Onto my review, I can see why Below Zero received negative responses from players. A lot of the game has been scaled down, in spite of the fact that they added a bunch of content in the game. Sure there are new things here and there, but what bothers me is how almost all the fauna in the previous game still exists in Below Zero but can no longer be cultivated or interacted with. The map has been significantly shrunk in scale, the Fauna in the game (Leviathans in particular) do not feel as intriguing as the previous game, the map feels a lot less interesting as well.

The progression feels a lot more open but also less interesting in general. In the previous game there is a vague order in which you unlock the blueprints that allows you to organically explore more of the game. In Below Zero blueprints feel more clustered together, which is explained as the planet having been recently inhabited,  but this comes at the cost of not having to explore much to acquire the necessary things to reach endgame. The music does not feel as notable or fitting compared to the previous game either.

That said I would still recommend Below Zero if you simply want more Subnautica. There are still some interesting ideas explored here and base building is still fun. Hopefully this is not the end of the franchise and the developers can explore and develop the ideas they could not fully realize in the past 2 games. Most of all I hope they are compensated and treated with the respect and dignity they deserve, Lord knows the industry doesn't care about them nearly enough.

Subnautica: Below Zero is a beautiful and atmospheric underwater adventure that builds on the strengths of the original Subnautica while adding a more narrative-driven experience. The Arctic biome feels fresh, with new creatures, biomes, and environmental hazards that keep exploration exciting. The world is smaller than the first game, but more detailed, and the improved base-building and vehicle options make progression satisfying.

The story is more prominent this time, offering clearer objectives, though some players may find it less mysterious than the original. Performance is generally solid, though occasional bugs still appear. Overall, Below Zero delivers a compelling mix of survival, exploration, and discovery—perfect for fans of the series or anyone who enjoys immersive worlds.

Absolutely wonderful. I was initially disappointed with the Seatruck in my first play-through, but grew to love it by the time I'd collected all of it's upgrades and possible modules. 

I simply can't get enough exploration in; of the underground landscapes, various plants and wildlife, and most of all, intelligent alien life. The mystery and story of the Architects are a lovely balance of ethereal and sci-fi.

My only grievance with the game is the same with the original: resource management is often cumbersome and time consuming the further you progress into the game. 

TLDR; Subnautica is the pinnacle of the underwater survival genre. Below Zero delivers just as the original did. The true sequel is highly anticipated.

Item sorting and management shortcuts are in desperate need, and expected (by me) to be in Sub 2.

I think that this game doesn't quite live up to the original, but i don't think it's a bad game at all. I like it for very different reasons than i liked the original Subnautica.

For one, if you're interested in the horror elements of Subnautica more than the survival ones, this game will be dissapointing to you. I found it significantly less scary. In fact, though the original game scares me so much that i can barely play it, this game i am very comfortable with, which should tell you a lot about the change in scary factor. The map it much smaller and much more densely populated. It's much more colorful and full of flora and doesn't quite have the same empty, desolate feel as the first game. This looks much better, yes, but it also makes the game WAY less scary. 

The Leviathans in this game are much less scary than in the first game, as well, and some of them are not very well liked by the community. I think the designs are really cool, but they aren't very scary. "Really cool but not scary" pretty much sums up my feelings about this game in general.

Now, as a SURVIVAL game, i think this game is fantastic! It's very fun and has some serious quality of life changes from the original, which was pretty grindy in my opinion. This game is VERY fun as a survival game. Though it's a bit lacking in vehicles compared to the first game- the seatruck replaces both the seamoth AND the cyclops from the first game- it's not a very big map so a huge submarine would feel a little out of place. The game is very well balanced, but has a lot less to explore and does a lot less with scale. Nothing this game has to offer is quite as epic as the first, somehow, despite being very important to the franchise's lore.

Now, about the story. This game's story is pretty divisive. For one, instead of a voiceless protagonist, your player character, robin, basically never stops talking, and it takes away from the experience in some cases because it removes your immersion. It's important that she talks because a lot of the game's story revolves around her relationship with another person who she frequently speaks with- and i do love their banter, but it takes away from the lonely and scary immersion of the original quite a bit. Also, some of the lines and pretty cheesy and corporate- the kind of stuff you'd probably see in any AAA survival game with a talking protagonist. Not the best dialogue, honestly. 

This game does have a surprising amount of LGBTQ representation, if that matters at all to you. Throughout the game's audio logs and optional story content there are several canonically gay characters in the story, which is pretty cool- it's treated very casually and is nice representation, rather than feeling pandering or out of place. The characters also have a lot of personality compared to the first, which i find interesting. 

Overall, this game is a downgrade from the original in a lot of ways but i wouldn't say it's bad at all. Subnautica was lightning in a bottle and i don't know if any other game the studio makes will ever capture the feeling of the original, and i don't think it's fair to really expect that, particularly now that a lot of the original Dev team is being replaced by Krafton's management team. As a long time fan of the series, it's deeply disappointing to see how the developers of this game have been treated by their own studio.  I wish the developers the best in their lawsuit and court case.

This game was absolutely stunning, and the plot-line was SO worthy of its predecessor. I looove Robin, and the other surprise characters we meet here. This map may be smaller than Subnautica's, but it's rich, extremely interesting to explore, and gorgeous. I absolutely adored every moment of this game, and I wish we would get even more of the aftermath. Truly I highly, highly recommend this game, ESPECIALLY for anyone who was even a little bit interested in the Architects in the first game. The additional lore we got in this one for them was PHENOMENAL. I was absolutely losing my mind over all of it.

(Scroll to the bottom for a TLDR)

I love the first game. It is by far my favorite game I have ever played. 

   I did not enjoy this one even remotely as much on my first play through. I do not like how Robin's character (the player) is written at all. No real scientist would act like such a child when talking to a different intelligent alien race. It didn't stop at Allen, she acts like a child for most of her interactions with other characters or when finding out new information. If I was Allen and Robin was the first human I met and only reference I had, I'd get the other Architects to exterminate all of human kind. I liked all of the other characters. Which is a shame because Robin is kind of an ass to them. So whats the fix for this if you just want an experience like the first game?
   Simply go into settings and turn the voices volume to 0% and turn the subtitles off. It improved my gaming experience by 70%. I have been able to replay it without cringing. Sure it can be a bit odd seeing the crazy gestures without any context, but it's fun to make up your own lines. That being said, I would like to say that all of the voice actors including Robin's did a great job with the scripts that they were given. They have great talent. It was only a writing failure that messed up the story. Which there is context as to why everything was all messed up. 


TLDR:
Turn voice volume to 0% to play a game almost like the first Subnautica.

I am divided if I should even recommend this game or not. There is a lot to unpack. 
First of all this game is much shorter than the predecessor. I mean like 2,5 times shorter (I have playtime of BZ 22h, while on first one 55h~). From this reason alone I highly recommend buying it on sale. 
With this said I will start from nice things - like the biomes and creature design. Stunning, I love it. I absolutely adore Sea Monkeys, crystal caverns, whale leviathans, penguins etc. However, this game is not even remotely scary. First game creeped you out. Here? Not really. Maybe a tiny bit of tension while exploring shipwreck for the first time. However if you want to play just new biomes and maybe experience the arctic subnautica - it's really enjoyable.
The thing is... It's the only thing it's good at? Lore is dead. Gameplay is kinda dead. It's short. Achievements are even easier than in the first one, they are not enjoyable, but they guide you what you should do in game. Game is not creepy. It's pretty tho.
The main plotline of sister is stupid as heck. You don't even notice and it's already done. You help the architect... And you learn literally NOTHING NEW about ANYTHING. You will probably end up more confused than understand... anything? Unless they totally change the planet for subnautica 2, I believe it's gonne be hard to write a proper lore for new game with this??? as a baseline.
I was thinking if the problem with our protagonist is about her talking so much and I think that maybe? I feel like it's more about what she is talking about rather then how much. Also the setting does not work - first part of Subnautica immersed you in the world not only because Riley was not talking - he was a lone survivor. You felt his situation, you were exploring, scared and confused. In Subnautica Below Zero however, our main character is literally here on her own accord. What's the point then? She is not lost and we don't even get any new knowledge about the world by interacting with architect. It just doesn't work. 
ALSO why does she have to talk this much amount of bullsh*t about hope, humanity and this pseudophilosophical sh*t? It turned out really shallow. She also says stuff like "I need to get to my droppod". Yeah, I know. You don't have to annouce every move of yours. This character turned out really unrealistic and as a pretty stupid one.
I hate the change of pda voice. I can't explain it but it just got on my nerves so badly.
First part of Subnautica suffered in the exploration of the ground. And this one suffered too. I kinda regret it, because the idea itself is good - I enjoyed finding and exploring some islands - creatures on the ground too. However walking was wonky. Snowfox is awful at best - both me and my boyfriend preferred to move in prawn. 
Nice of them to unlock earlier ion power cells, however everything was handed to you on a plate. All of extremely end game resources of Subnautica where available from the start in Below Zero. You end up not using anything what you scan. I didn't even unlock dock's for my seatruck because you literally don't need them. My bf didn't even get the high capacity tank XD.
While my base (while I really enjoy base building) in Subnautica was enormous, my base is Below Zero was small. Pretty, but simple and small. Why? Because you literally don't even need it in this game.  However there was more customisation available which was really nice, I hope in the future games there could be even more. 
I also wish the biodiversity would be even better. I think it was a good direction, but especially on the island it was visible how little creatures there are (literally 3 and a skyray lmao). 
Ending was crazily bad and made me laugh my ass off. It wasn't even funny, it was so stupid I just couldn't stop laughing.
I also believe it was much more enjoyable for me, because of playing it with my boyfriend. But for a solo run I don't think it's nearly as captivating as the first one.

TL DR: It's pretty. It's not a good continuation. May be enjoyable if you haven't played first part, but then it would be spoiling the first part while not even doing it in a worth of it way. If you just want more swimming in pretty places and to interact with creatures - go for it (on sale). However if you want a good continuation and a better game than the first one... You can just skip it. I think I wouldn't tho, but just because of need of experiencing stuff on my own.


[spoiler]Also in the end... Did she want to f*ck the architect? That was a crazy way to end the game. "I will go with you! I will continue my sis's legacy! You will find family!" That was really strange. I know the intent wasn't for that but I wouldn't be surprised if we get hibrid kids in some part.[/spoiler]

It's a DLC that's overwhelmingly unfaithful to the original game in many ways. It's only redeeming quality is the production quality on alien designs, fauna and flora. That specific visual matches the original and is wonderful.

The same cannot be said for everything else. There's considerably less explorable biomes, discoverable aliens. We lost the silent protagonist in favor of a diversity appeal that simply does not belong in any video game, and especially not as a follow up to the world-acclaimed silent protagonist experience that is the original Subnautica game.

It baffles me, this is so ridicule, so absolutely insane, it's a catastrophe. I'd put my hand to the fire that actual devs in the studio where forced into a toxic positivity environement as to never ever point out the self-sabotage, less they'd lose their jobs after the wonderfully successful first game.

It is a miracle we got a voice slider in the options, and something tells me it is no accident either. If my guess is right, whoever built that voice slider, Bravo, thank you. But even then, it wasn't enough. There's simply too much elements missing from the first game to meet anyone's expectations, and too many unbelivable garbage added instead.

I played below zero a few years ago and could simply not bring myself to finish it past collecting 2 alien part schematics and meeting the Strong Woman Character. I could only bring myself to play this again after enough time, after years without it, enough to forget the vivid regrets I had from my first experience, and I actually almost instantly abandonned immediately again straight into uninstall right back as the intro cinematic barely ended until I opened the options menu and found the way to mute the voices. Because immersion is king.

The story, main character, voice logs, all come from an obtuse "corporate are bad" and "toxic work environement and  coworkers" spiel that could have instead been about exploring an alien world, who knows. There is so much wasted effort in this meaningless crap, it is nauseating.

I play subnautica because I want to feel small as a grain of sand beneath the waves of an alien world, instead, this game lets you play as a diversity monologue that praises itself and wants you to ... well, that's about it, pretty much.

The amount of content the game offers is an adequate DLC, minus the characters. It is not enough content for a standalone game. It is not worth your money. It could have been a story of how there's frozen caraar left to expunge, it could have been a vastly simpler scenario without alterra meddling and without the terrible surface exploration, in favor of more time underwater, more time socializing with one single character: the robotic voice of your PDA, or perhaps an alien that needs help.

The production time on the surface level could have been spent on lonely, actual sub-nautica experiences below the surface of the water, which is what absolutely every single player was expecting. It truly hurts my heart that such a profound self-sabotage happened to one of my most favorite games ever.

The trailers and publisher's bonus loss to scam the devs and other various contexts of the next game are all known and shared amongst enthousiasts and I for one cannot bring myself to be hyped for it whatsoever. It already features that same Modern Audience look again. Dozens of thousands of players are uniformly begging to bring back the silent protagonist. I simply cannot care, cannot pay a single further cent of my money on what already looks like more of the same political The Message-driven self-sabotage, and neither should you.

I want to recommend this game so bad, but it was honestly just too big of a hot mess.

[b]The Pros:[/b] 
-	The snow themed biome was neat. I personal love games with snow in them (however… See Cons*)
-	Lots of cute animals and fish.
-	Offered the wonderful build system we experienced in the first Subnautica (albeit did not bring any new builds into the game for the most part).
-	Female protagonist (Would prefer character customization options but hey, it’s a start).

[b]The Cons:[/b] 
-	Game design in terms of mission continuity and map layouts was just atrocious. Ever biome is basically a maze with tons of dead ends, obstacles, haze, fog, snow, darkness -just miserable to navigate.
-	Story was deeply lacking. Whilst they tried to pad the story with “Heart” it ultimately came up feeling extremely pointless.
-	OMG an NPC we can interact with!!…. For like the first 10 min of the game… cool. But yay… [spoiler] vegetables from the garden... [/spoiler] Zzz
-	The Seatruck – [i] Dear Devs, yall know that a truck can pull heavy sh*t and move faster than 1km an hour… riiiiight? [/i] (Was so excited to learn about the modular system until I realized it turns the Seatruck into a SeaSloMoWhereTheFkDidIParkMySeamoth!) 
-	Visibility – touched on this above but visibility felt horrid in this game. Why am I squinting AF trying to not swim or run into walls constantly. Why am I getting lost constantly just because I can’t see where I am going. Why is there so much snow on land I can’t even see! I’m Canadian, I get that enough during January and February FFS!
-	Gathering – Can’t quite put my finger on this one but gathering just felt unsatisfying in Below Zero. In the first game it was exciting to locate a new resource. Might have been the cramped map or the frikken grind for Lead but I actually started getting annoyed having to look for resources. 
-	Map was just too damn cramped. Too many tunnels. Felt like they designed the map based upon a bowl of spaghetti dumped upside down. 

Rating: Below Zero out of Five Stars

PS: Why are yall trailers the nicest cutscenes the game has? Would love to see more cutscenes actually in-game once yall have taken my money.

The game starts OK but gets worse as the story moves on. The exploration of vast ocean from original Subnautica is mostly missing, the map is small and most things are hidden in complicated caves. Then it gets even worse with land areas. That is where i stopped playing. The land is a maze of corridors which are even worse than underwater caves because you can't swim up and down. In addition to that, you freeze if you are not in a vehicle. I honestly lost track of what am I supposed to do and find on the land and combining that with getting lost constantly, the game stopped being fun alltogether.

So, Subnautica was a fun play and pretty good game. IT has a few glitches and all but mostly plays well, is entertaining, has AMAZING replay and music, cool designs for the fish and leviathans, and draws you in.

Below Zero has none of that.

1: Glitches. The game ending glitches. Get out of the sea truck? freeze. Get in the sea truck? freeze. Get out of the base? freeze. SMGDH you'd THINK this wouldn't be an issue. You'd be wrong.

2: Entertainment. Hm. Well, you CAN enjoy it. Kinda. And Kinda is not good enough after Subnautica. THIS should have been AT LEAST just as good, but unfortunately it's "No, you can't have Subnautica, we have that at home". Below Zero fails at everything the OG succeeds at. No wonder. NO wow factor. No real scares or trepidation. Just a boring mess of a slog. 

3: Replay. I've only played the 34 hours at time of this review cause I get so dang BORED I have to quit and forget where I was and have to rebegin, OR I have to reset cause of all the FREEZES. FML man this game craps out WAY too often.

4: Music. The music here is crap. OG Subnautica had an amazing soundtrack and used ultrasonic frequencies in certain areas to PHYSICALLY CREEP YOU OUT. Below Zero just bores. 

5: Cool Designs? No. You want neat leviathans? Best I can do is 4 jawed dorks that all look the same and sound too similar, or annoying bs like TOO MANY CRYPTOSUCKS and brute sharks. Dude. Seriously. And sea monkeys that make you go thru this fmv bs that will get you eaten after they take something that could be vital to your life OR just crap. 

6: Drawing you in: No. No, all it does is drive you away. I get it: we all have different ideas. But dude. Seriously. Keep the sjw bs out of games. This is supposed to be a fantasy. It is already annoying to be harped on for eating meat and hearing your sissy characters whinge about fish in the first game, but this one? You literally did the cartman meme during your character designs. 

7: WTF why is it that all the stuff for endgame builds can be acquired in 2 hours, but you need a GD walkthru to find a Base Builder tool? TERRIBLE balance. The first game was SO AMAZING with this! And then there's BZ. Playing this is like watching the Globetrotters beat a middle school team. 

All in all, CAN you have fun? Sure. Is this game for everyone? No. Not at all. Is it even CLOSE to Subnautica? Hell no. This is Subnautica from Wish.Com. It is sad. 

One can only hope S2 is better.

I'm a big fan of the original Subnautica. Below Zero improves upon some of its gameplay elements, but falls woefully short in other areas. The main problem is the awful story and cringy characters. It feels like a typical 2020's project needlessly virtue signaling its woke political views. For example: all black girls are brilliant stoic badasses and all white men are goofy sissy boys. Is that something you enjoy in fantasy fiction? If so, you'll love this.

Below Zero might as well be a fan-made mod. And if it were, I’d probably cut it some slack. 

First, it’s much too small. Within a few hours you will be familiar with all the edges of the map (spoilers: it ends in disappointment).
But fine, it’s a tighter experience with much the same charm, right? Well, not really. The writing is worse, the tone is completely different, and the gameplay involves way too much land exploration and underwater spelunking. The frosty coat of paint and the new vehicles are cool in concept, but mostly just replace the better ones. Regarding the time on land, this game wasn’t built for it. But then again, shouldn’t that have been obvious?

I loved getting lost in Subnautica, and never truly felt like I had mapped it all out. I was fully immersed, stranded in an endless ocean, and always terrified. In Below Zero, I desperately went searching for that one cave I hadn’t yet seen, only to realize it’s the same as the one I had.

In case you’re looking at my playtime and thinking I got my money’s worth, here’s a quick rundown:  

I played this years ago, spent most of my time building a base, then stopped and thought: “what is this base even for? What larger goals will I contemplate inside this newly earned sanctum?” I couldn’t find an answer, and so I left my unfinished base and stopped playing. 

Fast forward to today. I decided to get further, start a new base, and had the much the same experience. If it weren’t for the game inexplicably failing to autosave after my last few hours of playtime, I probably would have kept going. But in hindsight I’m glad I had enough reason to stop.

If you want more Subnautica, and you likely do, this aint it.

Even taking it away from the comparison to its predecessor, this just isnt nearly as good as it could have been. Its riddled with bugs and MULTIPLE TIMES whilst playing I had to RESEARCH OTHER GLITCHES TO DO to get BACK IN BOUNDS! especially with the on land sections.

Removing it from that, yeah its alright. The story is... for sure something, and its really upsetting that to get the ending you don't even follow the story that the game tries to hook you with, its an optional side quest and the actual answer to your questions is *painfully* unsatisfying.

When the original Subnautica was a brilliant, thrilling thing, with a rich world and story that felt not like a game but like an experience, and Below Zero is none of that. I *really* hope Subnautica 2 can capture even a fraction of what made the original game so great, because this just doesn't.
Edit: The devs removed the option to play the legacy version of Subnautica, switching the review to negative.

There's a lot bad with this one. First I'd like to say that I gave this game a shot multiple times, I've 100% it twice and both times were mind numbingly boring. I absolutely love the first game, enough to make me speedrun it from time to time. So I was absolutely excited when they announced a second game. I've never been so disappointed in my life before. In Subnautica Below Standard, they offer more bad then actual good in terms of both gameplay and story. Which really felt like a step back for the series' direction considering how amazing the first game was. First. I'll talk about the good segments. The atmosphere, plants and scenery were all very good, all were very polished and you can see care went into into this part specifically. Now that we're done with all the good parts in this game and the only saving grace, lets talk about the bad parts of this game, and boy is there a lot.

First, the map. The map in this game feels so much more smaller and enclosed (because it is) when compared to the first game. Instead of having that really amazing feeling of getting lost and actually enjoy traveling like in the first game, you get a very watered down variant of it. Areas are a lot more small, less dangerous, and not as engaging as the first game. All the areas that were abandoned are all pretty small as well so you don't get that same feeling of trying to figure out what happened to the people that were there before. Traveling from place to place feels more like a chore then anything, there's zero danger in the waters and the violent fish are nothing more then a mere inconvenience to get through. Finally you're left with the surface segments. God they're so boring and the only slightly "exciting" thing is the huge worm that follows you. The actual places you can visit on the surface are also pretty lackluster. They offer really nothing other then a few key items and like a few novelties to decorate your base with. The worm is stupid easy to avoid, he does minimal damage so its not even a threat, and even if he was you cant even kill the dude. With the first game if you wanted a leviathan dead you could knife it to death or use a prawn suit, which was actually a really fun challenge to do. In Below Standard, you cant even hurt the worms because... well you're never really given a reason other then "they have thick shells" (which if you think about it, the prawn's drill can mine freaking diamonds, why the hell wouldn't it be able to drill the shell of a giant gummy worm.) 

Second, how the actual gameplay was implemented feels like if the devs taking a test 120 minute test with only 5 minutes left, did absolute zero work and didn't know the answers. So they copied the dude 4 seats ahead of them because they needed to write something down really quickly. Firstly all the materials you find in this game are either stupid easy to get, or really annoying to get. Which yeah you may think that's just normal game design but they made all the commonly used materials annoying to find, and the endgame stuff stupid easy to get. The first game at least had a way to get a lot of copper and quarts pretty easily, while in this one i had to go to 2 biomes over just to get a small handful. Hell even titanium wasn't this annoying to get in the first game. Now lets talk about the vehicles. The new vehicles in this game are often worse to use then just going out by yourself. The seatruck is a mix of the seamoth and the cyclop in the first game. I loved those two vehicles a lot but they somehow managed to get only the annoying things from those two, and put them into a single vehicle that's supposed to be your main source of transportation. The seatruck is pretty annoying to control, all of its segments are for specific uses so you cant even make it semi custom like in the cyclops.  Its also stupid slow too and often feels slower then using a seaglide just to get around. The other vehicle I used so rarely that I cant even remember it's name but its the hover bike that's in the screenshots. First, about that bike is that its stupid slow. So slow you cant even use it for the main thing it's designed to do, which is outrun and dodge the unkillable worms. When I played, I often had my bike get destroyed whenever the worm would poke its head out, roughly 20 meters away from me, which would kick me off of it instead of letting me outrun it. There is an upgrade from what I remember to make it *kinda* faster but that can be solved with what I mainly did, which was just using the prawn suit. They kept the prawnsuit in the game which meant you now have a proper way to travel both in the water, and on land. Which makes both the seatruck and bike totally useless. Sure you can get the other ones before the prawn suit but like, you'll never use them ever again after you get the prawn. At least with the cyclops you could bring it to the active lava zone without needing a prawnsuit to do anything down there. Oh also the prawnsuit is faster then both the seatruck and the bike, meaning its completely useless to use either in any situation, other then the prawn being too tall for some cave systems. 

Third, is probably one of the most important parts of any game, The story. My god is it such a HUGE step down from the first game. The story is you basically purposefully crash on an island to find your sister (who you already know is probably dead) to go find out what happened. Then you met a predecessor who invades your mind in the most obvious and uninteresting way. You then have to build the predecessor a body so then you can get him out of your head, so then you can finish the story. Which yeah that's can be a totally fine story, but how they execute it is awful. Firstly, Robin, the girl you play as is the most annoying character ever made. She whines and complains about every little thing, while boasting about how she's a survival expert and acts like the classic know it all. All her interactions with other characters just made me hate Robin more and more instead of wanted to see what her story was about. Not only that but she has pretty much zero character development. Second how they handled the infection was absolutely terrible. In the first game its really well polished with how they handle everything with it. In this one they kinda just make you combine a plant and if i remember correctly some salt and it cures the infection. So you're telling me that an infection that almost wiped out an entire plant could have been cured with some freaking fruits? Common fruits at that, that grew not even 100 meters away from the damn thing? Seriously, either they hired new writers who ruined the IP like with the halo show, or the devs were high on deepshrooms. The story regarding her sister was so bad I can even remember what it was about. I just remember she was dating someone and Altra didn't like the sister for whatever reason. I could be wrong with this part specifically so take that with a grain of salt, the story was hard to stay awake in. Finally you have the interactions with that old lady, they were the only decent thing in the story. Mainly since she had a cool dog but that was the only cool thing about her.  Honestly I don't really like saying this but Robin felt like a complete "Mary Sue", everything she does it feels like the devs were trying to make her one up the past MC. She feels like if the Forespoken devs were quickly asked to make a main character, and all that they had was a napkin. After making the draft they didn't like it so then they threw it away, then Unknown Worlds picked it up and used it for Robin character design. Robin's so god awful I cant tell if shes better or worse then the Forespoken MC.

This review is too long as I hit the text limit, don't waste your time or money. The music is somehow worse in this one, then compared to the first game which was amazing (I used to listen to it daily).

TLDR: The first game was better because the MC didn't talk in that one.

I am divided if I should even recommend this game or not. There is a lot to unpack. 
First of all this game is much shorter than the predecessor. I mean like 2,5 times shorter (I have playtime of BZ 22h, while on first one 55h~). From this reason alone I highly recommend buying it on sale. 
With this said I will start from nice things - like the biomes and creature design. Stunning, I love it. I absolutely adore Sea Monkeys, crystal caverns, whale leviathans, penguins etc. However, this game is not even remotely scary. First game creeped you out. Here? Not really. Maybe a tiny bit of tension while exploring shipwreck for the first time. However if you want to play just new biomes and maybe experience the arctic subnautica - it's really enjoyable.
The thing is... It's the only thing it's good at? Lore is dead. Gameplay is kinda dead. It's short. Achievements are even easier than in the first one, they are not enjoyable, but they guide you what you should do in game. Game is not creepy. It's pretty tho.
The main plotline of sister is stupid as heck. You don't even notice and it's already done. You help the architect... And you learn literally NOTHING NEW about ANYTHING. You will probably end up more confused than understand... anything? Unless they totally change the planet for subnautica 2, I believe it's gonne be hard to write a proper lore for new game with this??? as a baseline.
I was thinking if the problem with our protagonist is about her talking so much and I think that maybe? I feel like it's more about what she is talking about rather then how much. Also the setting does not work - first part of Subnautica immersed you in the world not only because Riley was not talking - he was a lone survivor. You felt his situation, you were exploring, scared and confused. In Subnautica Below Zero however, our main character is literally here on her own accord. What's the point then? She is not lost and we don't even get any new knowledge about the world by interacting with architect. It just doesn't work. 
ALSO why does she have to talk this much amount of bullsh*t about hope, humanity and this pseudophilosophical sh*t? It turned out really shallow. She also says stuff like "I need to get to my droppod". Yeah, I know. You don't have to annouce every move of yours. This character turned out really unrealistic and as a pretty stupid one.
I hate the change of pda voice. I can't explain it but it just got on my nerves so badly.
First part of Subnautica suffered in the exploration of the ground. And this one suffered too. I kinda regret it, because the idea itself is good - I enjoyed finding and exploring some islands - creatures on the ground too. However walking was wonky. Snowfox is awful at best - both me and my boyfriend preferred to move in prawn. 
Nice of them to unlock earlier ion power cells, however everything was handed to you on a plate. All of extremely end game resources of Subnautica where available from the start in Below Zero. You end up not using anything what you scan. I didn't even unlock dock's for my seatruck because you literally don't need them. My bf didn't even get the high capacity tank XD.
While my base (while I really enjoy base building) in Subnautica was enormous, my base is Below Zero was small. Pretty, but simple and small. Why? Because you literally don't even need it in this game.  However there was more customisation available which was really nice, I hope in the future games there could be even more. 
I also wish the biodiversity would be even better. I think it was a good direction, but especially on the island it was visible how little creatures there are (literally 3 and a skyray lmao). 
Ending was crazily bad and made me laugh my ass off. It wasn't even funny, it was so stupid I just couldn't stop laughing.
I also believe it was much more enjoyable for me, because of playing it with my boyfriend. But for a solo run I don't think it's nearly as captivating as the first one.

TL DR: It's pretty. It's not a good continuation. May be enjoyable if you haven't played first part, but then it would be spoiling the first part while not even doing it in a worth of it way. If you just want more swimming in pretty places and to interact with creatures - go for it (on sale). However if you want a good continuation and a better game than the first one... You can just skip it. I think I wouldn't tho, but just because of need of experiencing stuff on my own.


[spoiler]Also in the end... Did she want to f*ck the architect? That was a crazy way to end the game. "I will go with you! I will continue my sis's legacy! You will find family!" That was really strange. I know the intent wasn't for that but I wouldn't be surprised if we get hibrid kids in some part.[/spoiler]

As a standalone game, Below Zero is incredible. Great graphics, great performance, great music, and great gameplay- really, an amazing game... as a standalone. Because Below Zero just doesn't live up to Subnautica. The story isn't compelling (or even interesting, to be honest)- there is no real character development, no grand twist that engages the player- the free feel of exploring a vast ocean world is gone, and linear gameplay replaces it.

Is the game good? Yes. But it just doesn't live up to what it promised. And for that reason, I cannot recommend it.

I wish there was a "mixed" review option, but this game isn't great. It's about a 6/10. My main gripe is the level design, it just doesn't work. This game opted for a more enclosed space experience with small biomes and deep winding caves, but they aren't nearly as fun or memorable as the expansive, desolate biomes of the first game. I think the various biomes are visually stunning, but they aren't mechanically a good match for this game. Subnautica was always fun because of the fear of the unknown, being forced to push your comfort zones to get new resources, but this game just feels very same-y. Unfortunate, because it really does a lot of stuff right too! The base building is a direct upgrade from the first game, especially the seatruck dock! LOVE that thing!
Overall, I sort of enjoyed the game, but I cannot recommend someone to buy it. If you do, wait for it to be on sale for $10 or so, then I'd say it's worth a shot. It's a game I would probably not come back to.

Everything good about the core gameplay loop of Below Zero is either as good in OG Subnautica, or better.

The only reason I bothered to go back and finish the game (after walking away from it with disappointment over a year ago) was just how close I was to finishing up the storyline (that and the last three achievements bugged me juuuust enough). It sure as HELL isn't worth the £26 ($35 at current exchange rates) that it's currently listed at!

If you want it, wait for it to come up on a 75% off sale... or go play OG Subnautica and check out the modding community for that one.

It baffles me, this is so ridicule, so absolutely insane, it's a catastrophe. I'd put my hand to the fire that actual devs in the studio where forced into a toxic positivity environement as to never ever point out the self-sabotage, less they'd lose their jobs after the wonderfully successful first game.

It is a miracle we got a voice slider in the options, and something tells me it is no accident either. If my guess is right, whoever built that voice slider, Bravo, thank you. I played below zero a few years ago and could simply not bring myself to finish it past collecting 2 alien part schematics and meeting the Strong Woman Character. I could only bring myself to play this again after enough time, after years without it, enough to forget the vivid regrets I had from my first experience, and I actually almost instantly abandonned immediately again straight into uninstall right back as the intro cinematic barely ended until I opened the options menu and found the way to mute the voices. Because immersion is king.

The story, main character, voice logs, all come from an obtuse "corporate are bad" and "toxic work environement and  coworkers" spiel that could have instead been about exploring an alien world, who knows. There is so much wasted effort in this meaningless crap, it is nauseating.

I play subnautica because I want to feel small as a grain of sand beneath the waves of an alien world, instead, this game lets you play as a diversity monologue that praises itself and wants you to ... well, that's about it, pretty much.

The amount of content the game offers is an adequate DLC, minus the characters. It is not enough content for a standalone game. It is not worth your money. It could have been a story of how there's frozen caraar left to expunge, it could have been a vastly simpler scenario without alterra meddling and without the terrible surface exploration, in favor of more time underwater, more time socializing with one single character: the robotic voice of your PDA, or perhaps an alien that needs help.

The production time on the surface level could have been spent on lonely, actual sub-nautica experiences below the surface of the water, which is what absolutely every single player was expecting. It truly hurts my heart that such a profound self-sabotage happened to one of my most favorite games ever.

It already features that same Modern Audience look again. Dozens of thousands of players are uniformly begging to bring back the silent protagonist. I simply cannot care, cannot pay a single further cent of my money on what already looks like more of the same political The Message-driven self-sabotage, and neither should you.

As someone who loved the original Subnautica, I went into Below Zero with high hopes, but came away pretty disappointed.

The magic of the first game just isn’t here. The map feels claustrophobic and way too small, with tight spaces that suck the fun out of exploration. There’s no real sense of wonder or fear like there was in the original’s vast, mysterious ocean.

The Seatruck, which replaces both the Seamoth and Cyclops, somehow manages to be worse than both. It's slow, clunky, and awkward to use, especially in cramped biomes. Instead of feeling like a cool modular system, it just becomes a hassle and its faster to just take the seaglide.

Biomes in general are bland and forgettable. They all sort of blur together, mostly icy caves and shallow zones without much identity. The thrill of discovering strange new environments just isn’t there.

The voiced protagonist is cringe and annoying, the silent avatar from the first is so much more immersive. If you are a die hard fan get it, but its not even close to as good as the original. It feels more like an asset flip with some story thrown in.
It should have been a DLC, wait for a sale. if you bother at all.
loved the original, there was a lot of momentum built up for an amazing follow up, instead of naming it BZ they may as well of  just called it BS. Just a awful game

I want to recommend this game so bad, but it was honestly just too big of a hot mess.

[b]The Pros:[/b] 
-	The snow themed biome was neat. I personal love games with snow in them (however… See Cons*)
-	Lots of cute animals and fish.
-	Offered the wonderful build system we experienced in the first Subnautica (albeit did not bring any new builds into the game for the most part).
-	Female protagonist (Would prefer character customization options but hey, it’s a start).

[b]The Cons:[/b] 
-	Game design in terms of mission continuity and map layouts was just atrocious. Ever biome is basically a maze with tons of dead ends, obstacles, haze, fog, snow, darkness -just miserable to navigate.
-	Story was deeply lacking. Whilst they tried to pad the story with “Heart” it ultimately came up feeling extremely pointless.
-	OMG an NPC we can interact with!!…. For like the first 10 min of the game… cool. But yay… [spoiler] vegetables from the garden... [/spoiler] Zzz
-	The Seatruck – [i] Dear Devs, yall know that a truck can pull heavy sh*t and move faster than 1km an hour… riiiiight? [/i] (Was so excited to learn about the modular system until I realized it turns the Seatruck into a SeaSloMoWhereTheFkDidIParkMySeamoth!) 
-	Visibility – touched on this above but visibility felt horrid in this game. Why am I squinting AF trying to not swim or run into walls constantly. Why am I getting lost constantly just because I can’t see where I am going. Why is there so much snow on land I can’t even see! I’m Canadian, I get that enough during January and February FFS!
-	Gathering – Can’t quite put my finger on this one but gathering just felt unsatisfying in Below Zero. In the first game it was exciting to locate a new resource. Might have been the cramped map or the frikken grind for Lead but I actually started getting annoyed having to look for resources. 
-	Map was just too damn cramped. Too many tunnels. Felt like they designed the map based upon a bowl of spaghetti dumped upside down. 

Rating: Below Zero out of Five Stars

PS: Why are yall trailers the nicest cutscenes the game has? Would love to see more cutscenes actually in-game once yall have taken my money.

I'm a big fan of the original Subnautica. Below Zero improves upon some of its gameplay elements, but falls woefully short in other areas. The main problem is the awful story and cringy characters. It feels like a typical 2020's project needlessly virtue signaling its woke political views. For example: all black girls are brilliant stoic badasses and all white men are goofy sissy boys. Is that something you enjoy in fantasy fiction? If so, you'll love this.

Below Zero might as well be a fan-made mod. And if it were, I’d probably cut it some slack. 

First, it’s much too small. Within a few hours you will be familiar with all the edges of the map (spoilers: it ends in disappointment).
But fine, it’s a tighter experience with much the same charm, right? Well, not really. The writing is worse, the tone is completely different, and the gameplay involves way too much land exploration and underwater spelunking. The frosty coat of paint and the new vehicles are cool in concept, but mostly just replace the better ones. Regarding the time on land, this game wasn’t built for it. But then again, shouldn’t that have been obvious?

I loved getting lost in Subnautica, and never truly felt like I had mapped it all out. I was fully immersed, stranded in an endless ocean, and always terrified. In Below Zero, I desperately went searching for that one cave I hadn’t yet seen, only to realize it’s the same as the one I had.

In case you’re looking at my playtime and thinking I got my money’s worth, here’s a quick rundown:  

I played this years ago, spent most of my time building a base, then stopped and thought: “what is this base even for? What larger goals will I contemplate inside this newly earned sanctum?” I couldn’t find an answer, and so I left my unfinished base and stopped playing. 

Fast forward to today. I decided to get further, start a new base, and had the much the same experience. If it weren’t for the game inexplicably failing to autosave after my last few hours of playtime, I probably would have kept going. But in hindsight I’m glad I had enough reason to stop.

If you want more Subnautica, and you likely do, this aint it.

Even taking it away from the comparison to its predecessor, this just isnt nearly as good as it could have been. Its riddled with bugs and MULTIPLE TIMES whilst playing I had to RESEARCH OTHER GLITCHES TO DO to get BACK IN BOUNDS! especially with the on land sections.

Removing it from that, yeah its alright. The story is... for sure something, and its really upsetting that to get the ending you don't even follow the story that the game tries to hook you with, its an optional side quest and the actual answer to your questions is *painfully* unsatisfying.

When the original Subnautica was a brilliant, thrilling thing, with a rich world and story that felt not like a game but like an experience, and Below Zero is none of that. I *really* hope Subnautica 2 can capture even a fraction of what made the original game so great, because this just doesn't.
Edit: The devs removed the option to play the legacy version of Subnautica, switching the review to negative.

Compared to the original, this game is dog water. 

Smaller map, lame vehicles, less features (such as VR support), poorly designed enemy behavior, lame story, and the main character is insufferable. Plus, they got rid of the cyclops to replace it with an awkward and slow underwater bus. One of the most memorable experiences i had with the original was completing the cyclops and putting out fires when I face the first leviathan. The best part of the original was how it made you FEEL when you plunged deeper into the abyss for the first time to test a new piece of equipment. The FEELING where the visuals and music compounded the unique and exciting experience of exploring a terrorizing deep seascape. All of the mentioned shortcomings, including the bland music cues add up to a stale and forgettable experience. Didn't bother finishing this one.

There's a lot bad with this one. First I'd like to say that I gave this game a shot multiple times, I've 100% it twice and both times were mind numbingly boring. I absolutely love the first game, enough to make me speedrun it from time to time. So I was absolutely excited when they announced a second game. I've never been so disappointed in my life before. In Subnautica Below Standard, they offer more bad then actual good in terms of both gameplay and story. Which really felt like a step back for the series' direction considering how amazing the first game was. First. I'll talk about the good segments. The atmosphere, plants and scenery were all very good, all were very polished and you can see care went into into this part specifically. Now that we're done with all the good parts in this game and the only saving grace, lets talk about the bad parts of this game, and boy is there a lot.

First, the map. The map in this game feels so much more smaller and enclosed (because it is) when compared to the first game. Instead of having that really amazing feeling of getting lost and actually enjoy traveling like in the first game, you get a very watered down variant of it. Areas are a lot more small, less dangerous, and not as engaging as the first game. All the areas that were abandoned are all pretty small as well so you don't get that same feeling of trying to figure out what happened to the people that were there before. Traveling from place to place feels more like a chore then anything, there's zero danger in the waters and the violent fish are nothing more then a mere inconvenience to get through. Finally you're left with the surface segments. God they're so boring and the only slightly "exciting" thing is the huge worm that follows you. The actual places you can visit on the surface are also pretty lackluster. They offer really nothing other then a few key items and like a few novelties to decorate your base with. The worm is stupid easy to avoid, he does minimal damage so its not even a threat, and even if he was you cant even kill the dude. With the first game if you wanted a leviathan dead you could knife it to death or use a prawn suit, which was actually a really fun challenge to do. In Below Standard, you cant even hurt the worms because... well you're never really given a reason other then "they have thick shells" (which if you think about it, the prawn's drill can mine freaking diamonds, why the hell wouldn't it be able to drill the shell of a giant gummy worm.) 

Second, how the actual gameplay was implemented feels like if the devs taking a test 120 minute test with only 5 minutes left, did absolute zero work and didn't know the answers. So they copied the dude 4 seats ahead of them because they needed to write something down really quickly. Firstly all the materials you find in this game are either stupid easy to get, or really annoying to get. Which yeah you may think that's just normal game design but they made all the commonly used materials annoying to find, and the endgame stuff stupid easy to get. The first game at least had a way to get a lot of copper and quarts pretty easily, while in this one i had to go to 2 biomes over just to get a small handful. Hell even titanium wasn't this annoying to get in the first game. Now lets talk about the vehicles. The new vehicles in this game are often worse to use then just going out by yourself. The seatruck is a mix of the seamoth and the cyclop in the first game. I loved those two vehicles a lot but they somehow managed to get only the annoying things from those two, and put them into a single vehicle that's supposed to be your main source of transportation. The seatruck is pretty annoying to control, all of its segments are for specific uses so you cant even make it semi custom like in the cyclops.  Its also stupid slow too and often feels slower then using a seaglide just to get around. The other vehicle I used so rarely that I cant even remember it's name but its the hover bike that's in the screenshots. First, about that bike is that its stupid slow. So slow you cant even use it for the main thing it's designed to do, which is outrun and dodge the unkillable worms. When I played, I often had my bike get destroyed whenever the worm would poke its head out, roughly 20 meters away from me, which would kick me off of it instead of letting me outrun it. There is an upgrade from what I remember to make it *kinda* faster but that can be solved with what I mainly did, which was just using the prawn suit. They kept the prawnsuit in the game which meant you now have a proper way to travel both in the water, and on land. Which makes both the seatruck and bike totally useless. Sure you can get the other ones before the prawn suit but like, you'll never use them ever again after you get the prawn. At least with the cyclops you could bring it to the active lava zone without needing a prawnsuit to do anything down there. Oh also the prawnsuit is faster then both the seatruck and the bike, meaning its completely useless to use either in any situation, other then the prawn being too tall for some cave systems. 

Third, is probably one of the most important parts of any game, The story. My god is it such a HUGE step down from the first game. The story is you basically purposefully crash on an island to find your sister (who you already know is probably dead) to go find out what happened. Then you met a predecessor who invades your mind in the most obvious and uninteresting way. You then have to build the predecessor a body so then you can get him out of your head, so then you can finish the story. Which yeah that's can be a totally fine story, but how they execute it is awful. Firstly, Robin, the girl you play as is the most annoying character ever made. She whines and complains about every little thing, while boasting about how she's a survival expert and acts like the classic know it all. All her interactions with other characters just made me hate Robin more and more instead of wanted to see what her story was about. Not only that but she has pretty much zero character development. Second how they handled the infection was absolutely terrible. In the first game its really well polished with how they handle everything with it. In this one they kinda just make you combine a plant and if i remember correctly some salt and it cures the infection. So you're telling me that an infection that almost wiped out an entire plant could have been cured with some freaking fruits? Common fruits at that, that grew not even 100 meters away from the damn thing? Seriously, either they hired new writers who ruined the IP like with the halo show, or the devs were high on deepshrooms. The story regarding her sister was so bad I can even remember what it was about. I just remember she was dating someone and Altra didn't like the sister for whatever reason. I could be wrong with this part specifically so take that with a grain of salt, the story was hard to stay awake in. Finally you have the interactions with that old lady, they were the only decent thing in the story. Mainly since she had a cool dog but that was the only cool thing about her.  Honestly I don't really like saying this but Robin felt like a complete "Mary Sue", everything she does it feels like the devs were trying to make her one up the past MC. She feels like if the Forespoken devs were quickly asked to make a main character, and all that they had was a napkin. After making the draft they didn't like it so then they threw it away, then Unknown Worlds picked it up and used it for Robin character design. Robin's so god awful I cant tell if shes better or worse then the Forespoken MC.

This review is too long as I hit the text limit, don't waste your time or money. The music is somehow worse in this one, then compared to the first game which was amazing (I used to listen to it daily).

TLDR: The first game was better because the MC didn't talk in that one.

What the f*ck


I am divided if I should even recommend this game or not. There is a lot to unpack. 
First of all this game is much shorter than the predecessor. I mean like 2,5 times shorter (I have playtime of BZ 22h, while on first one 55h~). From this reason alone I highly recommend buying it on sale. 
With this said I will start from nice things - like the biomes and creature design. Stunning, I love it. I absolutely adore Sea Monkeys, crystal caverns, whale leviathans, penguins etc. However, this game is not even remotely scary. First game creeped you out. Here? Not really. Maybe a tiny bit of tension while exploring shipwreck for the first time. However if you want to play just new biomes and maybe experience the arctic subnautica - it's really enjoyable.
The thing is... It's the only thing it's good at? Lore is dead. Gameplay is kinda dead. It's short. Achievements are even easier than in the first one, they are not enjoyable, but they guide you what you should do in game. Game is not creepy. It's pretty tho.
The main plotline of sister is stupid as heck. You don't even notice and it's already done. You help the architect... And you learn literally NOTHING NEW about ANYTHING. You will probably end up more confused than understand... anything? Unless they totally change the planet for subnautica 2, I believe it's gonne be hard to write a proper lore for new game with this??? as a baseline.
I was thinking if the problem with our protagonist is about her talking so much and I think that maybe? I feel like it's more about what she is talking about rather then how much. Also the setting does not work - first part of Subnautica immersed you in the world not only because Riley was not talking - he was a lone survivor. You felt his situation, you were exploring, scared and confused. In Subnautica Below Zero however, our main character is literally here on her own accord. What's the point then? She is not lost and we don't even get any new knowledge about the world by interacting with architect. It just doesn't work. 
ALSO why does she have to talk this much amount of bullsh*t about hope, humanity and this pseudophilosophical sh*t? It turned out really shallow. She also says stuff like "I need to get to my droppod". Yeah, I know. You don't have to annouce every move of yours. This character turned out really unrealistic and as a pretty stupid one.
I hate the change of pda voice. I can't explain it but it just got on my nerves so badly.
First part of Subnautica suffered in the exploration of the ground. And this one suffered too. I kinda regret it, because the idea itself is good - I enjoyed finding and exploring some islands - creatures on the ground too. However walking was wonky. Snowfox is awful at best - both me and my boyfriend preferred to move in prawn. 
Nice of them to unlock earlier ion power cells, however everything was handed to you on a plate. All of extremely end game resources of Subnautica where available from the start in Below Zero. You end up not using anything what you scan. I didn't even unlock dock's for my seatruck because you literally don't need them. My bf didn't even get the high capacity tank XD.
While my base (while I really enjoy base building) in Subnautica was enormous, my base is Below Zero was small. Pretty, but simple and small. Why? Because you literally don't even need it in this game.  However there was more customisation available which was really nice, I hope in the future games there could be even more. 
I also wish the biodiversity would be even better. I think it was a good direction, but especially on the island it was visible how little creatures there are (literally 3 and a skyray lmao). 
Ending was crazily bad and made me laugh my ass off. It wasn't even funny, it was so stupid I just couldn't stop laughing.
I also believe it was much more enjoyable for me, because of playing it with my boyfriend. But for a solo run I don't think it's nearly as captivating as the first one.

TL DR: It's pretty. It's not a good continuation. May be enjoyable if you haven't played first part, but then it would be spoiling the first part while not even doing it in a worth of it way. If you just want more swimming in pretty places and to interact with creatures - go for it (on sale). However if you want a good continuation and a better game than the first one... You can just skip it. I think I wouldn't tho, but just because of need of experiencing stuff on my own.


[spoiler]Also in the end... Did she want to f*ck the architect? That was a crazy way to end the game. "I will go with you! I will continue my sis's legacy! You will find family!" That was really strange. I know the intent wasn't for that but I wouldn't be surprised if we get hibrid kids in some part.[/spoiler]

As a standalone game, Below Zero is incredible. Great graphics, great performance, great music, and great gameplay- really, an amazing game... as a standalone. Because Below Zero just doesn't live up to Subnautica. The story isn't compelling (or even interesting, to be honest)- there is no real character development, no grand twist that engages the player- the free feel of exploring a vast ocean world is gone, and linear gameplay replaces it.

Is the game good? Yes. But it just doesn't live up to what it promised. And for that reason, I cannot recommend it.

It's good by virtue of being a Subnautica game, but fails in every other regard. Completely abandons the environmental storytelling that made the first game stand out. Really, I just didn't care for the reddit alien. Play the original twice instead lol

I wish there was a "mixed" review option, but this game isn't great. It's about a 6/10. My main gripe is the level design, it just doesn't work. This game opted for a more enclosed space experience with small biomes and deep winding caves, but they aren't nearly as fun or memorable as the expansive, desolate biomes of the first game. I think the various biomes are visually stunning, but they aren't mechanically a good match for this game. Subnautica was always fun because of the fear of the unknown, being forced to push your comfort zones to get new resources, but this game just feels very same-y. Unfortunate, because it really does a lot of stuff right too! The base building is a direct upgrade from the first game, especially the seatruck dock! LOVE that thing!
Overall, I sort of enjoyed the game, but I cannot recommend someone to buy it. If you do, wait for it to be on sale for $10 or so, then I'd say it's worth a shot. It's a game I would probably not come back to.

Everything good about the core gameplay loop of Below Zero is either as good in OG Subnautica, or better.

The only reason I bothered to go back and finish the game (after walking away from it with disappointment over a year ago) was just how close I was to finishing up the storyline (that and the last three achievements bugged me juuuust enough). It sure as HELL isn't worth the £26 ($35 at current exchange rates) that it's currently listed at!

If you want it, wait for it to come up on a 75% off sale... or go play OG Subnautica and check out the modding community for that one.
